I observe that you have come from afar, with all the characteristics intact,

At that time, the Bodhisattva thought to himself:

Lampu is without wisdom, but I alone have wisdom. Lampu is without faith, but I alone have faith. Lampu is still able to attain this concentration, how much more so should I, who am progressing in learning, not attain supreme perfect enlightenment?
The Bodhisattva, having abandoned this concentration, did not attain supreme perfect enlightenment through this Dharma. He thought to himself and spoke this verse:

Revolving and falling into birth and death, calamities and disasters enter the darkness of the world.
At that time, the Bodhisattva further thought to himself:
This is not the essential path to nirvana. I shall seek the essential path to liberation again.
He again spoke this verse to Lampu:

At that time, the Bodhisattva continued to move forward to a secluded place, enduring hardship and eating only one grain of sesame and one grain of rice a day. At that time, the Bodhisattva spoke this verse:
The root of burning and moistening love is cut off by the wisdom of the mind,
The mind is the root of myriad thoughts, but the body is without enmity.
At that time, the Bodhisattva then, as he had thought, accepted the honey, ghee, milk porridge, and oil applied to the body offered by people.

At that time, the Bodhisattva had two Brahmin girls on his left and right who provided for his needs. The two girls milked five hundred cows to feed two hundred and fifty cows, and then milked two hundred and fifty cows to feed one hundred and twenty-five cows. They milked one hundred and twenty-five cows to feed sixty cows, milked sixty cows to feed thirty, and then milked thirty to feed fifteen. They milked fifteen to feed seven, and then milked seven. They then prepared food for the Bodhisattva. The milk boiled over the cauldron by one chi and then returned to the cauldron.
At that time, there was a physiognomist Brahmin who saw the boiling milk returning to the cauldron and said:
If there is someone who establishes the faculties and attains strength and eats this rice gruel, they will attain the unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
At that time, the two women filled a golden bowl with gruel and offered it to the Bodhisattva.

At that time, the evil MÄra brought 1.8 billion followers and MÄra's son Satya to the Bodhisattva's place. The Bodhisattva's power of kindness did not move a single hair, and he immediately attained supreme perfect enlightenment. The demon then retreated.

At that time, the TathÄgata gazed intently at the Bodhi tree without blinking. There were three merchants who had traveled far on the road and wanted to return to their homeland. The gods firmly blocked them, not allowing them to pass. The ox-drawn cart was stuck. The gods told them:

At that time, the TathÄgata did not want to accept it.
The reason for this is:
If I were to take food with my outstretched hand, it would be no different from the non-Buddhist brÄhmans.
I should now contemplate what food the Buddhas of the past used.
As soon as he had this thought, the gods in the sky said:
The Buddhas of the past all used alms bowls to eat.
As soon as he spoke, the Four Heavenly Kings presented four bowls, not made by craftsmen, but naturally accomplished.
At that time, the TathÄgata had this thought:
Now the Four Heavenly Kings have presented four bowls. If I accept one and reject three, or accept three and reject one, it is not appropriate. Now I will accept all four bowls.
He joined them into one bowl.
Then the merchants offered honey, ghee, and yogurt to the TathÄgata, and he immediately made a dedication verse:

Now, as for the offerings made, I wish to make those who eat them obtain sufficient energy and strength. I should cause the household that makes offerings to receive blessings and peace in generation after generation, to be without illness, to be able to protect their lifespan, to ultimately receive auspiciousness, to have peace and security for their two feet, peace and security for their four feet, peace and security for those coming from afar, peace and security for those present, peace and security at night, peace and security during the day, peace and security at noon, peace and security for all the seeds, peace and security for the entire household, peace and security without illness, peace and security for all the relatives, with many pure and clean foods, to be cured for a hundred years and to see a hundred years.
At that time, the World-Honored One remained silent and did not speak the Dharma for seven times seven, forty-nine days, thinking to himself:
I wish to make the other person come and request to receive it himself.

At that time, the people of Magadha heard that the Bodhisattva had already attained Buddhahood. Day and night, they sincerely thought of the TathÄgata. At that time, the World-Honored One gradually continued on his way. He first subdued five, then two fives, then thirty-seven, and then thirteen villages. At that time, there were sixty arhats in JambudvÄ«pa, with the TathÄgata as the sixty-first.

Therefore it is said, The people of Magadha are not negligent, and through purity, they attain rebirth in the heavens.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Not wishing to bring about fame, the wise discern the meaning,
Without negligence, the meaning is abundant, and is upheld by the wise.

Not wishing to bring about fame means that for the sages and those with right views, and for the disciples of the Buddhas and sages, such a person is praised. Such a person can remove negligence and cultivate pure practices. A person who is not negligent increases their meritorious virtues in wholesome dharmas and benefits greatly.

When a person in the world goes from this world to the next, encountering wholesome dharmas, encountering sages and saints, hearing the Dharma and immediately being liberated, it is all due to not being negligent that one obtains this fame. Wherever one is, one continues the Buddha's lineage and the true Dharma abides for a long time. Therefore, it is said, Not wishing to bring about fame.
The wise discern the meaning means that one who studies extensively also knows the meaning of the world and the meaning of the Way.
What is meant by knowing the meaning of the world?

Or cultivating fields and planting crops, or going to sea to collect treasures, or learning writing and literature, or studying mathematics and astronomy, or learning to carve seals and store them, or serving as the king's envoy to communicate with distant places, or reconciling two opposing parties and placing them in a state of non-action, such worldly affairs are all accomplished through diligence.
How do the wise understand the meaning of the Way?
Sitting in meditation, reciting sutras, and assisting in various affairs.
What is meant by sitting in meditation?

Those who sit in meditation and enter concentration can attain the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship, and attain the first, second, third, and fourth dhyanas, the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, and the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, and further attain the four immeasurables of kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity, the supernormal powers, the divine ear, the knowledge of others' minds, the recollection of past lives, and the ability to see sentient beings passing away and being reborn.

A person who is not arrogant enters the state of concentration, accomplishes these dharmas, and attains the supreme truth. This is due to being undistracted. A distracted person will never accomplish anything. This is called the merit obtained by the person who sits in meditation.
What is reciting the sÅ«tras?

One is able to recite the sÅ«tras, vinaya, abhidharma, miscellaneous scriptures, and the sÅ«tras recited by non-Buddhists. If one receives and accepts them, one will not be stingy with their meaning. If non-Buddhists come to question, one will be able to answer without hesitation.
An undistracted person is able to practice this Dharma, but a distracted person will not be able to accomplish it.
What is assisting with various tasks?

At that time, a person who is not negligent can encourage the four groups to serve the Three Jewels and build stupas and temples, or build lecture halls that are warm in winter and cool in summer, or build dining halls, repair and supplement deficiencies, scatter flowers, burn incense, and sprinkle the ground with fragrant water, to provide for the Sangha of the past, future, and present. A person who is not negligent can accomplish these things, while a negligent person cannot accomplish them. Therefore, it is said, The wise discern the meaning.

As for the meaning of abundance without negligence, a person who is not negligent has abundant wealth and treasures, and lacks nothing in worldly skills. If they wish to practice, they can surpass the crowd and collect genuine pearls, agate, carnelian, amber, crystal, and priceless maá¹‡i jewels. Renouncing the world to study the Way, attaining arhatship, attaining the supreme wonderful wisdom, seeing the realization of the body, attaining the emptiness of emptiness samadhi, attaining the wishlessness of wishlessness samadhi, attaining the signlessness of signlessness samadhi, attaining this essential path of nirvana, all due to non-negligence. Therefore it is said, the meaning of non-negligence is abundant.

As for what is received by the wise, when speaking of the wise, it means being free from leakage, always speaking with a smile without harboring arrogance, and being able to give rise to such virtues. A foolish person cannot accomplish this. Therefore it is said, what is received by the wise.ğŸ”½The meaning that exists in the present,
as well as the conditions of the next world,ğŸ”½The warrior is able to expound,
This is called a wise person.

As for the meaning of what is present, a person who is not negligent gains much wealth and naturally receives blessings in the present Dharma, is remembered by others, follows their words and accepts their teachings. A negligent person does not have this. Therefore, it is said, The meaning of what is present.

As for the causes and conditions of the next world, a person who is not negligent can become a human next, and then can give, keep precepts, and maintain purity. Seeing those who practice the Way, they rejoice on their behalf. With the fragrance of various good dharmas, they perfume their bodies. For hundreds and thousands of lifetimes, their appearance is upright. Therefore, it is said, The causes and conditions of the next world.

As for the hero who can expound, it is to respond according to the time without losing its place. As for the so-called hero, the Buddha and his disciples are it. Therefore, it is said, The hero who can expound.
This is called a wise person who can accomplish various dharmas, discern and contemplate, lead people, show them what is good, and remove their evil.
Monks who are careful and diligent are happy, while the negligent have much to worry about.
They are able to escape the difficulties of the deep sea, like an elephant pulling itself out of mud.

A wise person saw this and asked:

The people replied:

The wise person asked:

At that time, the wise person immediately assembled drums, horns, gongs, and drums, making sounds like in battle, and also had the crowd all take up weapons. It then broke free from the deep mud and rushed towards the army, galloping in the four directions seeking a battle.
At that time, King Prasenajit asked those around him:
Who had the power to pull the elephant out of the mud?
Those around him said to the king:
There was a wise person from afar who devised this strategy and was able to save the elephant from danger.
The king then rewarded him and appointed him as an advisor.
At that time, there were many bhiká¹£us who saw with their eyes and heard with their ears, and then calculated for themselves:

However, we people are mired in the sea of birth and death, not escaping the difficulties of the five paths. We have the troubles of birth, old age, sickness, death, and poisonous fears, and cannot pull ourselves out. We chase each other, and when one body is destroyed, we receive another body. Moving with sin, we revolve through the six paths, seeking to escape without hope.

At that time, the bhiká¹£us diligently practiced day and night without time to eat or rest, like putting out a fire or avoiding the burning of a kalpa. They vigorously practiced the Dharma and burned away their afflictions, like iron a hundred times tempered into a tool, which must be sharp.

People are also like this. When the knots are removed and the mind is present, they suddenly greatly awaken and attain the fruit of arhatship, with the six spiritual powers clear and penetrating, and freedom in life and death.

At that time, the World-Honored One, with his pure divine eye free from defilement, knew that the bhiká¹£us were resolute in their determination and unwavering in their faith, each encouraging one another, and also knew that the fighting elephant had pulled itself out of the mud.

For the sake of future sentient beings, he made a great torch of illumination, and also caused the true Dharma to long abide in the world, proclaiming the great teaching far and near, and while in the great assembly, spoke this verse:
Bhiká¹£us, being careful is joyful, while being lax brings much worry and fault.

As for bhiká¹£us, being careful is joyful, bhiká¹£us who uphold the practice are not lax in their minds, are pure inside and out without any defilements, roam with an unconditioned mind without attachment or pollution, and therefore it is said, bhiká¹£us, being careful is joyful.

Carelessness brings much worry and fault means that it is the source of many fears and faults, and the loss of a country or the destruction of a family is all due to it. It is like fire, like a thief, and also like poison. A careless person's mind is confused, falls into evil destinies, and enters a deep abyss by oneself, and also teaches others to enter the abyss. There are many fears, and from the beginning there is no joyful mind. Therefore, it is said, Carelessness brings much worry and fault.

Hungry ghosts, animals, and hells are like this. If one wants to seek even a tiny bit of goodness from the three paths, it cannot be found. One who is able to save oneself

Like an elephant pulling out mud - at that time, the fighting elephant had this thought in its mind:

In the past, I have received the king's favor and enjoyed delicious food. I have fought with the king and never failed to subdue him. If I were to sink in the mud today and not be able to extricate myself to fight with the king, then I would lose my long-standing reputation and also cause the entire country to be disgraced.
Therefore, it is said, Like an elephant pulling out of the mud.

The great mass of afflictions is burned by the fire of wisdom. This is not due to the teacher, but naturally awakened by oneself. Later, sentient beings who are able to emulate this are the highest among learners. Thus, monks!
You should seek the highest learning, do not engage in the lowest learning.
Monks, being careful brings joy, while negligence brings many worries and faults.
Bound and wrapped by afflictions, one is burned to the end by the fire.

At that time, many monks practiced the Way day and night. The grasses in the ground were extremely luxuriant and did not see each other. The bandits ran wild there, terrorizing the monks who were practicing the Way.

At that time, many monks practiced the Way day and night. When it was time, they entered the city to beg for alms. On the way, they encountered the king's collection of taxes and profits, which were sent to the royal treasury.

Understand the meaning and analyze the phrases, practice cessation and abide in eternal peace.

He saw that they each diligently cultivated, fearing regression in their realization. He wished to make the great Dharma long remain in the world, to be a great torch of light for future beings. In the great assembly, he spoke this verse:
Monks, being careful brings joy, while negligence leads to much worry and fault.
Disputes arise from small beginnings, and accumulating evil leads to being burned in the fire.
When anger and rage are rampant, even cold water boils.
When evil reaches its limit, the consequences are endless.
Day and night, one should be diligent and firmly uphold the precepts.
One will be respected by good friends, but not thought of by bad friends.

As for day and night, one should be diligent, why is it said that diligence is the characteristic of avoiding non-dharma, leaving behind unwholesome states, being diligent in wholesome states, diligently extinguishing defilements, and completely eliminating wrong views, inverted thinking, and doubts? It is also seeking skillful means to remove the bonds of habit. Therefore, it is said, Day and night, one should be diligent.

As for firmly upholding the precepts, the bodily, verbal, and mental deportment is well-cultivated with wholesome thoughts, the mind is like a diamond that cannot be destroyed, and one firmly grasps the precepts without giving in to external wrong views.
As for the precepts, there are two hundred and fifty precepts.

Firmly upholding and guarding them without being lazy or negligent, one should guard the precepts as if one were crossing a river without discarding the raft. When desire, anger, and ignorance arise, one should stop them from arising. Therefore, it is said, firmly upholding the precepts.

As for being respected by good friends and not being thought of by bad friends, good friends are those with right views who cultivate the true Dharma and attain accomplishment. They are all respected and remembered by such people. Bad friends are those with bad knowledge and understanding who are far from both sides. When they see good people cultivating morality and virtue, they harbor jealousy and do not wish to hear or see them. Therefore, it is said, not being thought of by bad friends.
Also not practicing what has been cultivated,
Sleepiness and not seeking awakening, this is called entering the deep abyss.

As for lack of mindfulness and negligence, one often forgets and errs, the nature of the mind is confused, and whatever one does with the mind becomes unwholesome. Wholesome thoughts are thus extinguished and unwholesome thoughts increase and arise. Having already given rise to unwholesome thoughts, one then falls into an evil destiny and is disliked by others.
A negligent person thinks day and night, I will abandon this and go to that, or gives rise to a harmful mind and various thoughts. Therefore it is said, lack of mindfulness and negligence.
As for lack of mindfulness and what has been cultivated, the mind is always indolent. Having already given rise to indolence, one is abandoned by both the path and the laity.
How is one abandoned by the laity?
As the Buddha's sutras say, for an indolent son of a wealthy family, there are six unrighteous ways of receiving punishment.
What are the six?

Matters that should be done quickly are not done, matters that should be drawn out are not done, after a full meal one does not do what should be done, after extreme hunger one does not do what should be done, after extreme heat one does not do what should be done, after extreme cold one does not do what should be done.
This is called the six unbeneficial methods of receiving punishment for the lazy son of a wealthy family, who cannot attain the unsurpassed true path. This is called being abandoned by the laity.
What is meant by being abandoned by the path?

In this case, a bhiká¹£u does not recite the sÅ«tras, the Vinaya, the Abhidharma, and the miscellaneous canon, does not sit in meditation or recite the sÅ«tras, and does not assist in the affairs of the saá¹ƒgha. In the present life, he does not reach the ultimate and is unwilling to cultivate. He is never cultivated in the path and the laity.
How is it that he is not cultivated in the laity?
The mind is not anxious to cultivate livelihood, wealth, and non-livelihood wealth.
What is meant by livelihood wealth? Elephants, horses, cattle, sheep, slaves, servants, and workers are called livelihood wealth.
What is meant by non-livelihood wealth?
Gold, silver, the seven treasures, grain, food, fields, and occupations for livelihood - these are called wealth that is not life.
Storing them in an insecure place, they are invaded by thieves - this is called what is not practiced by the worldly.
What is not practiced in the path?

Not guarding the senses, the previous thought gives rise to the subsequent thought, and evil follows thought after thought, not allowing good thoughts, just as a river flowing down a mountain, if someone wants to cut it off in the middle and prevent it from flowing, it is ultimately impossible.

The same is so for a person who is negligent, evil follows thought after thought, if someone wants to give rise to a good mind between the previous and subsequent thoughts, it is ultimately impossible.
The reason for this is that evil thoughts follow thought after thought, therefore it is said, Also not practicing what is cultivated.

As for not seeking to awaken from sleep, it is like a person who sometimes listens to the Dharma in the assembly, but is oppressed by sleep and cannot awaken, or sometimes speaks with people but immediately falls asleep. Only the wise can admonish them, either by admonishing with harsh words, or by scolding them, or by using skillful means to first anger and then delight them.
Therefore, the World-Honored One appears in the world of the five turbidities, and expounds to people the burning Dharma of birth and death.
If one can discern the origin of suffering, then there will be no more of this Dharma of myriad afflictions.
Not seeking skillful means in the wholesome dharmas, one's days of decline and dissipation increase the practice of having outflows. Therefore, it is said, Not seeking to awaken from sleep.
This is called entering the deep abyss. The precepts have two functions.
What are the two?
First, the two hundred and fifty precepts are pure like true gold;
Second, not extensively cultivating and learning the wholesome dharmas, seeking to exhaust the outflows and attain the realization of the undefiled.
They also do not seek to attain the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, the fruit of non-returning, or the fruit of arhatship.
They are unwilling to associate with these dharmas, and then fall into a deep abyss without reaching the ultimate. This is called the practitioner falling into a deep abyss.
What is meant by the worldly falling into an abyss?

If a person in the world does not practice riding elephants, driving horses, holding hooks and throwing ropes, fighting dangerously and deceptively, advancing and retreating, and does not cultivate them all, then they will sink and be unable to manifest their name and virtue, and their family business will not be accomplished. Therefore, it is said, This is called falling into a deep abyss.ğŸ”½One should seek to remove past faults,
So as not to lose one's mindfulness,ğŸ”½And not give rise to arrogance at any time,
Delightfully practicing good dharmas,ğŸ”½Good dharmas are well-abiding sleep,
In this world and also in the next.

Those who seek to remove past offenses are like people who have been to the ocean and know the passages and roads into the ocean. They think, In such and such places there are water and drinks, in such and such places there are gambling houses, in such and such places there are brothels. They should remember to stay far away from such places.
If they reach the ocean, there is a fruit called madana, which they should not pick or eat. If they eat this fruit, they will not be able to obtain precious treasures.

The one who upholds the precepts is also like this. They show people the direct path and should remember to avoid gatherings of non-dharma. If they enter a gathering of non-dharma, they will not be able to obtain the profound Dharma.

It is like a person who is originally not familiar with the road. If they want to go somewhere, they will encounter obstacles and lose their belongings. Those who follow the direct road and do not take the wrong path will safely return home.

The same is true for the inner dharmas. Guarding the wholesome dharmas prevents external evils from entering, and always contemplating them does not let them leave the mind. Therefore it is said to seek to remove past faults and not lose mindfulness of them.
How does one not give rise to arrogance in a timely manner?

Always mindful of timely non-arising of jealousy and arrogance, always having a courageous mind without harboring laziness, the will to leave carelessness, all dharmas, and gather various wholesome qualities, just as a warrior can repel external difficulties by donning armor and holding weapons, the mind not being timid, the hands holding bow and arrow, the feet not moving, and then no longer fearing external enemies.

Bhiká¹£us are also like this. Grasping the mind firmly, giving rise to a great vow, and binding oneself, removing the thieves of afflictions and also having no doubts or difficulties. Therefore it is said not to give rise to arrogance in a timely manner.
How does one quickly practice wholesome dharmas?
What is meant by the Dharma is wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate.
The World-Honored One said:
Contemplate the elimination of unwholesome and indeterminate [thoughts], and cultivate wholesome dharmas.
Why is it so?

Unwholesome dharmas lead people into evil, indeterminate dharmas cause people to fall into delusion, and wholesome dharmas cause people to be born in good places, in the heavens and among humans, or enter the realm of the unconditioned nirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore it is said, Delight in cultivating wholesome dharmas.
What is meant by wholesome dharmas, good sleep?
No longer fearing falling into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals.
If people insult [one], do not harbor fear, sleep peacefully and calmly, and always be at ease upon waking. Therefore it is said, wholesome dharmas, good sleep.
In this world and the next, whether in this world or not, there is no worry, sorrow, or suffering.
Why is it so?
It is because of cultivating wholesome dharmas.
If reborn in the next world, encountering sages and not leaving wholesome places, this is due to the continuity of the body cultivating wholesome [actions].
Therefore it is said, in this world and the next.
Contemplate and be vigilant, be benevolent and learn the traces of the benevolent,
From this there will be no worries, remember to extinguish one's own mind.

As for contemplating and being vigilant, remove the five bonds and attachments, do not dwell in the five places, contemplate all day long leading and guiding the bhiká¹£us to cultivate and uphold the precepts.
The precepts have two functions.
What are the two functions?
First, the two hundred and fifty precepts, second, the function of the precepts of flexibility and compliance.

Speaking gently and no longer harming others, accepting the teachings of all practitioners of pure conduct, hearing the teachings of the Dharma and being able to follow them, not losing the path of liberation of the sages, therefore it is said, contemplate and be vigilant.

Studying benevolence and following the traces of benevolence, from this there is no worry. The mind is concentrated and not disturbed. Internally cultivating kindness and compassion, extending to all beings, not practicing desire, anger, or ignorance, but only contemplating the abandonment of desire, seeking to enter the chamber of tranquil concentration. Therefore it is said, Studying benevolence and following the traces of benevolence, from this there is no worry.
How should one contemplate the extinction of one's own mind?

One should always be mindful and guard the mind without disturbance. Do not seek their faults or hope for their conduct. Having attained right concentration, external delusions do not enter. The evil Mara Paplyana cannot find an opportunity.

Or transforming their robes, appearing as parents, brothers and sisters, coming in, deceiving good men and women, cannot find an opportunity. The mind has attained concentration and never forgets the wholesome dharmas without outflows. Having attained the wholesome dharmas, one then receives the Tathagata's name. Having received the name, the Buddha Dharma then endures for a long time. Therefore it is said, One should contemplate the extinction of one's own mind.
Seeking the essential well, following the Buddha's teachings,
Will extinguish the multitude of deaths, like an elephant emerging from a flower chamber.

Seeking the essential well means quickly seeking skillful means, seeking good companions well, being disgusted with birth and death, greed and desire, and distancing oneself, and further seeking to contemplate the impurity of the body. Although dwelling in birth and death, the mind is not tainted or attached to birth and death.
Essential means to be born in the world, and also to leave the three realms of existence and not receive rebirth again.
Essential refers to leaving the household life to study the Way and cultivate the unsurpassed Way, leaving behind family affairs.
Essential means to expose one's essence and be self-reliant, not seeking cover.
Therefore it is said, Seeking the essential well.
Following the Buddha's teachings - how does one follow the Buddha's teachings?
Upholding the correct view of oneness, not attached to heretical teachings, in accord with practice, not lacking in the determination for the Way.
What does it mean to be in accord with practice?
It means attaining arhatship.
What does it mean not to lack in the determination for the Way?
It means to eliminate all fetters and unwholesome dharmas, without wrong or inverted views.
Those who go against this Dharma are not in accord with the Buddha's teachings. Therefore, it is said to be in accordance with the Buddha's Dharma.
As for destroying the multitude of death, what is called the multitude of death?
It is the one hundred and eight fetters.
Seek the means to destroy them and prevent their arising.
It is further said, What is the multitude of death?

It refers to birth, old age, and sickness. Also, seek the means to destroy them and prevent their arising. Erect the banner of great vows, beat the drum of the four equalities, summon those who receive the teachings to leave behind birth, old age, sickness, and death, hang the banner of liberation, spread the great sound and fill the world, and universally announce to all crawling and flying beings:

I have now attained the path of perfect enlightenment, exhausted birth and death, established the practice of purity, accomplished what is to be done, and will not again undergo existence. I know this as it truly is.

You should also exhaust the source of birth and death like me, enter the city of fearlessness, and no longer experience the various afflictions and transmigrations of birth and death.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Therefore it is said, One should extinguish the multitude of death.

As for the elephant emerging from the flower room, in the past there was a person who caught a large elephant and tied it with an iron chain to King Prasenajit. The elephant was extremely violent and caused immeasurable harm to the people, sometimes even harming other elephants, destroying the market stalls, uprooting fruit trees, and was unstoppable.
King Prasenajit then sent a group of people to capture and bind it, and closed it in a flower room, chaining it and not giving it food, still violent and difficult to control.
At that time, the king's family was attacked by another violent elephant, all of them donned armor and weapons to go on an expedition.
The method of elephant warfare is that when attacking, they must all shout in unison.

At that time, the chained elephant heard that there were external invaders coming to encroach on the territory, and the elephant became angry, broke the chains, and trampled the flower room to pieces. It ran around east and west, challenging the enemy as it went. When the people saw this, they all became terrified.

At that time, the World-Honored One, with his pure divine eye free from defilements, saw that the rampaging elephant had been untied and was on its own, seeking eternal peace by destroying its great enemy.
The TathÄgata was about to manifest his bravery, to show great illumination for future beings, and also to make the true Dharma long remain in the world. He spoke this verse in the great assembly:
Seeking the essential well, following the Buddha's teachings,
Will destroy the multitude of deaths, like an elephant leaving a flower room.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:

When a dragon elephant appears, it must benefit. Although it is an animal, its past wisdom is extremely deep. Born in a place of eight difficulties, away from benevolence and righteousness, hearing that many elephants are wearing armor and holding weapons, wanting to attack external enemies, obeying the order and calling together, when the elephant king hears it, he will be startled and run, fearing he cannot avoid danger.

Even animals, being foolish and ignorant, are still like this, let alone you monks who personally follow the TathÄgata, hearing the meaning of phrases, the meaning of flavors, the body of phrases, and the body of flavors, yet are unable to sever the bonds, afflictions, and attachments, and depart from birth and death, binding yourselves in prison.
He further addressed the fourfold assembly:

The bonds of the world are not solid, they are dangerous, fragile, and subject to decay. One is unable to abandon the household life, sever the mind of longing and love, and leave worldly causes and conditions. One does not think of the Way oneself, nor does one teach others to practice the Way.
An elephant, even when bound, after not many days, will seek liberation and find a place of non-action.

You sentient beings are attached to birth and death, and the bodies you have accumulated in the past are as numerous as the mountains in the ten directions. The tears you have shed from seeing the dead are like the four oceans in the ten directions. The hair of people is as numerous as the grasses in the ten directions, yet you still cannot escape from various difficulties, like a person with heavy crimes who is transferred three times a year, going in and out of prison, not reforming his faults and seeking liberation. Why are you so attached to indulgence and not seeking liberation?
Always staying at home, with many defiling activities, raising a wife and children, the heavy fetters of the household, thinking of seeking methods to abandon the mind attached to affection.
At that time, the people all suddenly awakened, their minds opened up and they sought to leave the household life and pursue the Way.
We have severed the fetters of worldly life, and we should now find a way to sever the fetters of birth and death.
With focused effort, day and night without stopping, each in turn attained the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship.
At that time, the TathÄgata saw that the bhiká¹£us had each attained the path and praised them, saying:
Excellent!

For the sons of great clans who practice in accordance with the truth, the reason the sons of clans shave their heads and faces, wear the three Dharma robes, leave the household life to study the path, cultivate the unsurpassed pure practice, end birth and death, establish the pure practice, accomplish what is to be done, and no longer accept existence is to truly understand it.
Accepting the offerings of faith from others is not in vain, and one is able to be a field of merit for others.

Not only do I now praise you, those who have attained the path all praise it. One is able to benefit oneself and also able to benefit others. Passing on the benefits to each other, then the Buddha's lineage is not cut off, and the true Dharma also abides in the world for a long time.

If there are sentient beings who, with their robes, food and drink, bedding and bedding items, and medicine for illness, hold and give them as gifts, they will obtain immeasurable blessings that cannot be fully described.ğŸ”½If one does not give rise to a careless mind
toward this true Dharma,
Cutting off birth, old age, sickness, and death, one transcends suffering and reaches the other shore.
Those who abide in this true Dharma, their inner cultivation and learning are all called the true Dharma.

Without harboring negligence or indulging in one's own will, one will no longer enter the womb to undergo various births. Although one may still undergo birth, one will be born in a central country and exhaust the root of suffering. Therefore, I say the original root of suffering.
Therefore, it is said:
If one abides in this true Dharma, without a negligent mind,
Cutting off birth, old age, sickness, and death, one transcends suffering and reaches the other shore.
